awd_titl_txt: RI: Student Travel Program for the 2018 International Conference on Case-Based Reasoning
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant supports travel costs for approximately 20 U.S. select students participating in the Doctoral Mentoring Consortium (DMC) at the 26th International Conference on Case-Based Reasoning (ICCBR), which will take place from the 9th to 12th of July 2018 in Stockholm, Sweden. This is the premier international conference for researchers in the field of case-based reasoning research across a fully international research community. This activity will bring together a broad community of researchers in the field of AI, and in particular, in research involving systems that encode, retrieve, and re-use experiences, enabling an automated form of reasoning-by-analogy.  The activity supports junior researchers at a critical early-career stage, and creates the opportunity to bring in participants who might not have attended an AI conference due to lack of resources. This is especially true for those at smaller institutions and those which have less developed AI programs. Engaging such participants has the potential to draw more talent into AI research, improve research ideas in their formative stage, and engender collaborations across the breadth of disciplines.  This event provides students with invaluable exposure to outside perspectives on their work at a critical time in their research and enables them to explore their career objectives.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The International Conference on Case-Based Reasoning is an associated meeting at the largest case-based reasoning conference in the world. The 2018 International Conference on Case-Based Reasoning (ICCBR-18) and its doctoral consortium occurred on July 9th-12th, 2018 in Stockholm, Sweden. The grant created an opportunity to bring in participants who might not have attended a case-based reasoning conference due to lack of resources. This is especially true for those at smaller institutions and those which have less developed programs. It provided an opportunity for PhD students to share their work, to receive mentorship from leading AI researchers, and to network with peers and industry professionals. This grant allowed ten computer science doctoral students from around the United States and American students attending international institutions to attend ICCBR-18, and it funded their travel, lodgings and sustenance.

Although the development of each doctoral student is necessarily personal, ICCBR-18 offered multiple opportunities for both technical and professional development of the participants. On the technical side, the participants were exposed to ongoing research in diverse areas and potentially found new collaborators for their current efforts. On the professional side, the speakers and conference panelists offered an opportunity to increase the effectiveness and future potential of the attendees. In summary, this grant better prepared the participants in completing their research and leading a career in computer science, artificial intelligence, and case-based reasoning.


Last Modified: 08/09/2022
Modified by: Michael T Cox
